newsitem.title: MALI: U.S. SEEKS NEW SANCTIONS ON NIGERIA - CHRISTOPHER.
newsitem.headline: U.S. SEEKS NEW SANCTIONS ON NIGERIA - CHRISTOPHER.

text.p: The United States, concerned about the deteriorating situation in Nigeria, is launching a fresh effort to bring additional sanctions against the military regime there, U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher said on Monday.

Beginning a five-nation trip to sub-Saharan Africa, Christopher told reporters on his airplane that Nigeria is among the topics to be discussed with leaders in Mali -- his first stop -- Ethiopia, Tanzania, South Africa and Angola.
His talks with heads of states in those African countries will be followed up by consultations with European allies and other African states, U.S. officials said.
Christopher did not give any details of the suggested additional sanctions, but U.S. officials ruled out that it would include a blanket oil embargo.

Citing human rights abuses and corruption as two key problems, Christopher said Washington "continues to very troubled by our relationship with Nigeria...as much because of the tremendous potential Nigeria has and the failed promise of Nigeria".
Back in the late 1970's Nigeria seemed to have unlimited opportunity to become a world leader as well as in Africa but that was "forfeited", Christopher said.
There were "limmerings of hope last spring" that Nigeria might be turning around when the military regime released seven political prisoners but "that promise has not been fulfilled", he said.
"I think we'll be starting a round of consulations with commonwealth countries and our European allies to see if we can find support for taking further action," he added.

The United States earlier this year discussed with African countries and European allies applying targeted collective sanctions against Nigeria but was told that was "not the right time", said a senior U.S. official who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity.
The new initiative will assess whether views have changed.

Relations between Nigeria and the West reached a low point in November last year with the hanging of nine minority rights activists including author Ken Saro-Wiwa for murder despite international pleas for clemency.
The wave of condemnation and limited sanctions imposed by western countries have forced Nigeria to announce a political reform process but the West said the timetable was very long.

In Christopher's talks this week in Africa and in the subsequent consultations, the adminstration will make clear its view that "pressure without dialogue is unlikely to yield anything as is dialogue without pressure", the official said.
U.S. officials refused to say publicly what specific new sanctions are being considered.
But some officials said privately that the U.S. proposal centres on freezing Nigerian assets held in overseas accounts, imposing restrictions on new investment in Nigeria and severing sporting ties.
Officials said the plan is to re-introduce the package of sanctions proposed earlier this year.

They said they continue to believe that a unilateral embargo on oil imported from Nigeria does not make sense and there continues to be no appetite in the U.N. Security Council for an international oil embargo.
The United States imports roughly 40 percent of Nigeria's exported oil with the rest going to Europe and Asia. Nigerian imports accounts for about seven percent of U.S. oil needs.

President Clinton in 1993 banned visas for members of Nigeria's regime to visit the United States. A ban on arms sales is in place and Nigerian diplomats are restricted from travelling outside a 25-mile radious of New York and Washington.
In addition, the United States opposes international financial assistance for Nigeria, in part because of its alleged involvement in narcotics trafficking.
